author: jgm
content:
I've seen "consensus chain" and "execution chain", with "beacon" being used in place of consensus now and again.  These seem to be suitably descriptive (consensus chain used to come to consensus, execution chain used for execution of transactions), although it may be slightly less so once we have sharding.

This also maps to the general uses of the term consensus layer and execution layer.

author: pietjepuk
content: EC would be "Execution Client" to me.

author: pietjepuk
content: I also kind of dislike the potential inference of there being two separate chains still with "Execution Chain" and "Consensus Chain". To some extent that is indeed the case, but I'd say there being _one_ chain (with a consensus layer, an execution layer, and also L2 layers on top of the latter) is more accurate.

author: tersec
content: see the confusion here about different notions of block number across the chains though

author: tersec
content: they are distinct.

author: pietjepuk
content: block numbers? I thought the beacon chain only had slot numbers

author: tersec
content: sure, the terminology is different, but there's been confusion even in this channel about, generically, the coordinate systems not overlapping between the two chains.

author: tersec
content: also, that they are distinct chains means that there exist failure modes (in theory, with ethereum nodes complying with relevant specifications, should be avoided, but a true single chain would not have them at all) where there's divergence.

author: tersec
content: the end-user communication part involves communicating about sync progress. again, it'll be two chains and it'll behave like it.

author: pietjepuk
content:
Fair enough, but I feel it very much depends from what perspective you looking at "the chain(s)". A user interacting with Ethereum now won't notice there being another chain after the merge, and the notion of another chain would be rather confusing to them.

For node operators/those running clients, many are already accustomed to "beacon chain", let alone the pieces of software referred to as "beacon node" and "validator client" on the consensus side.

author: jgm
content:
We're a bit weird in that we do actually only have a single chain of blocks, but two separate states (execution and consensus) that come from it.

None of the names are 100% accurate, and I don't think any name will make everyone happy, so we may as well pick one of the current crop of names for the consensus side (either beacon or consensus chain, I prefer the latter but not enough to fight about it) and stick with execution on the old ETH1 side.

author: pietjepuk
content: I have no issue adopting consensus chain as a synonym (or replacement of) of beacon chain, but that rename is not going to magically make everything clearer I'm afraid.
